Forrest Gump.Action: Compliments the nurse’s shoes sincerely, showing interest in her comfort.
Reflects on his mother’s sayings with affection and shares them openly.
Thoughtfully considers the meaning behind shoes and the story they tell about a person.
Recalls his first pair of shoes as 'magic shoes' that would take him anywhere, showing hopeful confidence despite physical challenges.
Walks stiffly with orthopedic shoes and leg braces, struggling physically but attempting to move forward.
Narrates the origins of his name and family history frankly and without judgment.
Allows his mother to help him with his stuck leg brace without frustration or complaint.
Pulls his foot out of the grate himself after his brace gets stuck.
Struggles physically due to braces impeding movement.
Holds tightly onto his mother's hand while she comforts him.
Listens to and internalizes his mother's message of equality and self-worth.
Sits patiently outside the principal’s office, showing calmness and acceptance.
Momma explains things simply so Forrest can understand them.
He's described by the principal as having an IQ of seventy-five, implying limitations in traditional measures of intelligence.
Momma encourages Forrest by telling him he is no different than anybody else, fostering confidence and self-worth.
Waits patiently outside the principal's office without complaint.
Sits quietly on the porch, showing calmness and acceptance despite situation.
Listens quietly during the principal's meeting about his IQ and school placement without protest or confusion.
Shows no active resistance or understanding of the situation regarding his schooling and IQ.
Grunts playfully imitating the principal, causing the principal to feel embarrassed and leave.
Listens attentively as his mother reads to him, showing engagement and closeness.
Grunts in imitation of the principal, showing simple social engagement but not much verbal communication.
Asks his mother a basic but thoughtful question about the meaning of 'vacation' and where his father went.
Welcomes travelers to stay at his home, including a young man with a guitar, showing hospitality and friendliness.
Dances oddly and enjoys interacting with the guest, showing openness and good-natured behavior.
Holds onto a broom and dances oddly when Elvis is playing guitar.
Looks himself in the mirror while dancing, enjoying the music and his dance.
Politely refuses to take a ride from the bus driver initially, showing caution but then quickly establishes friendly familiarity by saying 'Well, now we ain't strangers anymore.'
Refuses to take a ride from a stranger despite the bus driver encouraging him, showing caution and adherence to his mother's advice.
Introduces himself politely and establishes familiarity before proceeding, which helps defuse a potentially challenging situation.
Attempts to find a seat on the bus but is immediately rejected and does not assert himself or find an alternative confidently.
Sits next to Jenny on the bus and engages in conversation despite being shy and unsure.
Responds politely and sincerely to Jenny's teasing and questions, including shaking her hand.
Shows loyalty and friendliness by spending a lot of time with Jenny and sharing experiences like climbing and reading together.
Sits next to Jenny and initiates conversation despite social awkwardness.
Uses magic shoes to help correct his physical disability, showing practical problem-solving.
Responds calmly and confidently when teased about being stupid.
Learns to climb trees and read with Jenny's help, showing willingness to learn.
Does not show signs of understanding or analysis of social cues deeply, relying instead on direct responses.
Stays longer with Jenny to comfort her despite his own worries.
Tries to run away from bullies despite physical limitation and Jenny's urging.
Tries to run away from the bullies despite his physical limitations caused by braces.
Allows himself to be hit repeatedly by boys throwing dirt clods without effectively defending or escaping immediately.
Runs away from boys chasing him despite physical limitations and pain, showing determination and innocence.
Runs faster despite leg braces and pain, ultimately breaks free from braces and runs with speed and confidence.
Initially struggles due to leg braces but does not give up and continues trying to run.
Knocks on Jenny's door and runs toward her when he sees her, showing concern and willingness to find her.
Responds attentively to Jenny's situation at home without judgment or fear despite her father's drunkenness.
Runs quickly and confidently away from chasing boys and covers large distances without hesitation.
Knocks on Jenny’s door and speaks to her directly, showing initiative and social confidence in approaching someone he cares about.
Follows Jenny into a potentially dangerous situation despite signs of conflict with her father, implying a naive or uncalculated decision.
Feels happy that Jenny is living with her grandmother nearby, showing care for her well-being.
Welcomes Jenny to stay at his house when she is scared, offering comfort and friendship.
Calmly follows Jenny's lead to hide from her threatening father without panic or confusion.
Prays with Jenny when asked even though he may not fully understand the situation, showing emotional support.
Does not take active steps to intervene or protect Jenny from her father's aggression beyond compliance and hiding.
Runs away when bullied by older boys throwing rocks and shouting insults.
Runs determinedly despite being chased and mocked by boys.
Runs past teammates without selfish intent, just pursuing his goal.
Initially misunderstands racial slur and refers to it as raccoons, showing innocence but naivety.
Expresses surprise and curiosity about black students wanting to attend the same school.
Walks toward the schoolhouse despite tense and hostile atmosphere, indicating openness and possible courage.
Forrest shows confusion about the racial integration situation, asking what is going on and misunderstanding the word 'Coons' as 'raccoons'.
Forrest walks toward the schoolhouse despite not fully understanding the situation, showing initiative to engage or witness the event.
Notices a black girl drop her book and steps past policemen to return it to her.
Waves at people from the schoolhouse door in a friendly and non-confrontational manner.
Notices the young black girl dropping her book and promptly picks it up to return it to her.
Walks through a tense crowd during a major civil rights event calmly and politely interacts with people.
Waves to the coaches in a simple, friendly manner but does not verbally engage or assert himself.
Politely engages in brief conversation with a Black woman at the bus stop, shows interest in small details.
Sits outside Jenny's dorm in the rain, showing dedication by visiting her frequently.
Punches the boy who was hurting Jenny to protect her.
Offers Jenny chocolates and apologizes after intervening.
He opens the car door and punches the boy inside who was hurting Jenny.
Offers chocolates and apologizes, then says he'll go back to college, showing polite and appropriate behavior after the incident.
Does not escalate beyond defending Jenny; accepts Jenny's lead afterward without resistance.
Looks at Jenny with curiosity and innocence, looks away feeling ashamed when Jenny removes her bra, apologizes sincerely after an intimate moment.
Responds honestly and simply to Jenny's questions, showing straightforwardness but limited understanding of adult relationships.
Looks at Jenny's underwear and shows embarrassment, indicating a lack of experience and awkwardness in intimate situations.
Allows Jenny to guide him in an intimate moment despite his uncertainty, demonstrating trust and openness though lacking confident control of the situation.
Allows Jenny to lean on his shoulder and hugs her back when she kisses him on the cheek.
Remarks about ruining Jenny's roommate's bathrobe but shows no malice and focuses on Jenny's feelings.
Runs energetically and joyfully during the football game, encouraging the crowd and responding to their cheers.
Runs successfully across the football field evading defenders to score a touchdown, responding to the crowd's signals by stopping at the end zone.
Expresses dizziness and awkwardly mentions possibly ruining the roommate's bathrobe during an intimate moment.
Enjoys meeting the President and shares his simple, sincere delight in free food and drink without pretense.
Plays so much football that college 'ran by real fast' for him.
Selected for the All-America Team and meets the President of the United States.
Focuses on drinking many free Dr. Peppers instead of engaging with the event meaningfully.
Responds honestly and simply to President Kennedy by saying 'I gotta pee,' eliciting a smile from the President.
Acknowledges the tragedy around President Kennedy and his brother with quiet reflection, showing empathy.
Sits on the bus bench and openly admits he wouldn't understand the difficulty of being brothers, demonstrating sincerity and humility.
Accepts his college diploma humbly and respectfully, responding well to the dean’s congratulation.
Responds to President Kennedy's question honestly but awkwardly by saying 'I gotta pee.'
Uses the bathroom and observes items around him calmly, showing situational awareness.
Reflects thoughtfully on the shootings of President Kennedy and his brother, showing emotional processing but limited understanding.
Walks onto the stage and accepts his college diploma after five years of playing football.
Receives the degree and acknowledges the achievement modestly.
Allows Mrs. Gump to take his diploma, shows respect and appreciation to his mother.
Sits quietly when rejected seats on the army bus instead of causing conflict.
Shakes hands with Bubba and listens attentively to his story.

Does not demonstrate active initiative or expertise in the shrimping business in this excerpt.

Responds simply and directly to orders without overcomplicating or questioning.

Observes the environment and interacts calmly with Bubba.

Holds hand up to protect face and allows Bubba to lean against him for comfort in the rain.

Passively describes enduring constant harsh weather without complaint or apparent proactive action.

Agrees simply and positively to Bubba's shrimping business plan.

Turns back in the middle of danger to look for his friend Bubba, prioritizing his friend's safety over his own escape.
